title: 109_hr4303
content: The Act titled "Securing Equity for the Economic Development of Low Income Areas Act of 2005" expands the New Markets Venture Capital Program. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to require the selection of companies from each geographic region for the New Markets Venture Capital Program. The Administrator must select at least one company from each region submitting applications. Additionally, participation in the program is now mandatory for the Administrator. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to require small manufacturer participation agreements, with at least one agreement with a company focused on small manufacturers. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration must submit a report to Congress within one year evaluating the success of the New Markets Venture Capital Program expansion. Establishment of Office of New Markets Venture Capital under Title II of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. The Office of New Markets Venture Capital is established in the Investment Division of the Small Business Administration, headed by a Director appointed by the Administrator. The Director's responsibilities include administering the New Markets Venture Capital Program, assessing and advising on program changes, and expanding small business participation in the program. Authorization of $1,000,000 for the New Markets Venture Capital Program to encourage investment in small manufacturing and other related duties as determined by the Administrator. SEC. 4. LOW-INCOME GEOGRAPHIC AREAS. Modification of the definition of low-income geographic areas for the New Markets Venture Capital Program to ensure that the median family income in a specific tract does not exceed 80 percent of the greater of the statewide median family income or the metropolitan area median family income. This amendment also applies to the capital requirement for private capital raised under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. The Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to study the availability of equity capital in low-income urban and rural areas. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration will conduct the study and submit a report to Congress within 90 days. SEC. 5. CONDITIONALLY APPROVED COMPANIES. Operational Assistance Grants to Conditionally Approved Companies: The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to include grants for conditionally approved companies. Companies must repay the grant if they do not enter into a participation agreement for final approval. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 now allows for grants to conditionally approved companies, with a maximum grant amount of $50,000. If a company receives a grant and final approval, the grant amount is deducted from the total operational assistance grant. Additionally, the time limit for final approval is set at 2 years. SEC. 6. The Administrator will create standard documents for final New Markets Venture Capital Company approval applications within 60 days of enactment to reduce application costs. SEC. 7. Authorization of appropriations. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to reauthorize the New Markets Venture Capital Program for fiscal years 2006 through 2008. Funding amounts are adjusted, with $100,000,000 for paragraph (1) and $25,000,000 for paragraph (2). Additionally, $1,000,000 is authorized for Manufacturing and Regional New Markets Venture Capital Companies to support small manufacturers.
